hotspots.hotspot:
Local Trial Courts

Two types of disputes can be heard in local or state trial courts. Civil cases involve a dispute between two or more private individuals or organizations—usually over money or ownership. Criminal cases are those in which the state brings charges against someone for violating the law.

Court of Claims

Established in 1982, the U.S. Court of Federal Claims handles claims against the United States for money damages. A person who believes that the government has not paid a bill for goods or services may sue in this court. Headquartered in Washington, D.C., the court hears cases throughout the country.

Court of International Trade

This court hears cases dealing with tariffs. Citizens who believe that tariffs are too high—which raises the prices of imports—bring most of the cases heard in this court. It is based in New York City, but judges also hear cases in other major port cities, such as New Orleans and San Francisco.

Tax Court

Congress established the Tax Court to hear cases from citizens who disagree with the Internal Revenue Service or other Treasury Department agencies about their federal taxes. Based in Washington, D.C., the Tax Court hears cases all over the United States.

hotspots.hotspot:
Antitrust Violations

The U.S. Department of Justice sued Microsoft for antitrust violations in 1997, saying Microsoft illegally required PC manufacturers to include Internet Explorer. Microsoft's action had effectively shut out a competitor.

Weights and Measures

The government requires that all weights and measures be uniform, such as a gallon of gas. This promotes fair competition because gas companies cannot profit by measuring "smaller gallons" of gas and charging more.

Insider Trading

The U.S. government prosecutes individuals who use inside information to buy or sell stock before the information is made public. This is an attempt to ensure that all buyers and sellers can fairly compete in the market.

Safety and Advertising

The U.S. government promotes competition by requiring all food manufacturers to publish their ingredients. The government also prohibits false advertising claims about food to ensure that consumers know what they are buying.

hotspots.hotspot:
Taxes

The U.S. government collects taxes, such as the personal income tax. Tax dollars go to many programs, including the military, education, and highways, as well as safety net programs.

Welfare

Welfare programs have changed a great deal over time. The U.S. government has multiple programs to help people in poverty, including cash payments, food stamps, and free or reduced-price medical care.

Social Security

Social Security provides benefits to retirees. Working people pay into the system, and checks are sent to retirees. This program helps ensure that older Americans have an adequate standard of living.

Minimum Wage

The U.S. government imposes a minimum wage to ensure that the lowest-skilled workers will earn enough to pay for essentials like housing, food, and clothing.

hotspots.hotspot:
Pollution

Many industries cause pollution, from paper mills to oil refineries to large-scale farms. The federal or state government may use fines or regulation to stop firms from polluting.

Superfund Site

The U.S. government may designate a specific area as a Superfund Site. Then the government uses tax dollars to pay for the cleanup, while seeking payment from the polluting firm. There are 1,300 Superfund sites on the National Priority List.

Immunizations

Education and immunizations are positive externalities. State governments provide public education for all students, and designate immunizations for those who cannot afford them.

hotspots.hotspot:
Recession

Although there are always some workers unemployed, the number of job-seekers rises during economic downturns called recessions. The unemployed struggle to provide food, housing, and other necessities.

Inflation

Inflation, or rising prices, is a major problem in an economy. Periods of high inflation erode consumers' purchasing power and their confidence.

Monetary Policy

The Federal Reserve (or "Fed") can combat inflation by reducing the money supply. The Fed also tries to combat unemployment by increasing the money supply and lowering interest rates.

Fiscal Policy

During a period of high unemployment, Congress might spend money on a jobs program or cut taxes to encourage individual spending. During a period of high inflation, Congress might raise taxes or cut spending to take money out of circulation.
